text:
Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. A. Taylor
Address: 10th Avenue, Saskatoon
Birthplace: Wellington, Norfolk, England

1. Introductory Questions
   - What year did you start homesteading in Eastern Canada? Fall of 1906.
   - Where did you set up housekeeping? Woman Sack, fall 1908.
   - Where had you been living before that? Yorkshire, England.
   - For how many people did you prepare meals? 3 then 4 more.
   - How far was it to your nearest store? At Dewdney Sack, 4 miles.
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Summer, once in 2 or 3 weeks.
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? In winter about once in a month.

"We came west to homestead in the fall of 1906. (Bride & groom)"

2. Flour and Other Grain Products
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household.
   - And that made very good bread, cakes, etc.
   - In what quantities did you buy it? One 100 lb sack at a time.
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $5.50.
   - How much did you use Graham flour?
   - Whole wheat flour? Yes, we often had this on hand.
   - Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? About 20 miles.
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 80¢.
   - What other grain products did you use?
     - Cornmeal? At times.
     - Whole wheat?
     - Farina? Yes.
     - Other?
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.
   - How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $5.98

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Bee Hive was one.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs for family use.

At what price? $4.50 for 10 lbs.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Kept no cows in early years. Bought milk from nearby boys - 3/4 mile away.

Butter? Bought it when available - 2 miles away.

Eggs? 20-25 dozen.

What was the price of butter? 20¢ to 40¢ lb.

Did you pick eggs for interest? Yes, some times. Found best way was to pack in box & clean oats. Turned box once weekly.

Did you make butter? Not all 1913 cheese? Once weekly.

What kind of cheese? Only cottage cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? After freeze-up, we usually bought a good cut of beef & 25 to 50 lbs pork from neighboring farmers.

How did you get fresh meat? During summer months got some from town men & again.

How often did you get fresh meat? Summer - once in a month - perhaps.

How did you preserve meat? Several times used "Ma Cobbs" (from "The Northwest Farmer") recipe for Corned Beef. It was very good.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes, very good.

If so what year was it organized? But we didn't join it.

Did you use game? Would get it. What kinds? Moose a couple of times. Found it tough & stringy. Had mallard ducks once fall. They were most delicious! Poveshickens in season.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Also puddings.

We got almost no fresh fish except frozen fish in winter.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Used canned salmon & sardines during summer.

Kinds?
3. SEASONS AND STORING

In what quantity did you buy milk? (e.g., 1 gallon, 5 gallons)
What was the price for a ton of sugar? (e.g., $2.50 per ton)
What was the price of butter? (e.g., $2.50 per pound)
Did you store food in the attic? (e.g., yes, no)

4. DAILY PRACTICES

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?
What was the price of butter? (e.g., $2.50 per pound)
Did you pack eggs for storage? (e.g., yes, no)
Did you make cheese? (e.g., yes, no)

5. FAMILY LIFE

What was your favorite meal in the early years? (e.g., roast beef, fried chicken)
How often did you get fresh meat? (e.g., once a month, twice a month)
Did you have a garden? (e.g., yes, no)
Was there a "near farm" in your neighborhood? (e.g., yes, no)

6. FOOD SOURCES

Did you use canned goods? (e.g., yes, no)
Did you have a refrigerator? (e.g., yes, no)
Did you have a stove? (e.g., yes, no)
Did you have a sink? (e.g., yes, no)

7. FAMILY ACTIVITIES

What was your favorite activity in the early years? (e.g., reading, sewing)
Did you have a pet? (e.g., yes, no)
Did you have a dog? (e.g., yes, no)
Did you have a cat? (e.g., yes, no)
6. Beverages

What kind of tea did you buy? Lipton's
At what price? About 50¢ per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground
Price? About 40¢ lb.
What other beverages were used? Chocolate
Some neighbors made Root Beer, dandelion etc.

7. Vegetables and Dried Fruits

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
About 50¢
Could you get potatoes at the store? Sometimes
If not, where from? Bought some from neighbors who had started
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1918, Cabbage 1911, Carrots 1910, Onions 1911
Turnips 1911, Beets 1910

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lbs. (for 2 adults)
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk at first
What weight? 50 lbs.
How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? We bought by box in town—Kelandia
What was the price of prunes? 7¢ 5¢ 10¢ per lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, once apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. Preserving

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ………………
peas? Yes, corn? ……… beans? ……… Saskatoons? ………
other foods? ………………………………………………………………

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1907
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1927
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? Not till 1916
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? I do only small lots of any canning. Family of 11 children are all married & in their own homes.
To what extent? …………………………………………………………
Did you make your own winegar? I tried it once with raisins & soft water. It was poor, weak stuff.
3.

6. What kind of tea did you buy? 
   Saffron tea. 
   At what price? 

7. Vegetables and dried fruits:
   What was the price of potatoes per bushel? 
   Can you get potatoes at the store? 
   If not, where from? 
   How much did you pay for your own supply for the winter? 
   Turnips 19/11 
   Carrots 19/11 
   Cabbage 19/11 
   Beets 19/11 
   In what quantities did you buy these items? 
   How did you buy them? (In bulk or by the box?) 
   How did the grocer handle them? 
   What weight did you get? 
   How much did you pay per lb.? 
   What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? 
   Apricots, prunes, loganberries, raisins, currants or other? 

8. Preserving:
   In what year did you first preserve any foods by canning? 
   What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 
   What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 
   Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? 
   To what extent? 
   Did you make your own vinegar? 
   Did you make your own wine? 
   Did you make your own soft drinks?
These articles were almost all available at the stores in our early days. We dealt at stores in Harris, Zealandia, Later Milden, and at our country store in the old Dinmore Postal district.

I cannot remember exact prices of some of these groceries. Our main problem was not lack of such things in the stores, but lack of cash.

Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) about 20¢ per lb. We usually bought 3 or 4 lbs. at a time.

Baking

What type of yeast did you use? At first Royal Yeast cakes.

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes, using starters.

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Yes.

Did you make your own baking powder? I did once but it was cheaper than what we could buy.
These articles were almost all available at the store in our early days. We dealt in stores in Florida, Nebraska, later in Idaho, and at our country store in the old Sunnyside Hotel district.

Our main problem was not lack of such things in the store, but lack of each.

10. Baking

What type of yeast did you use? At first Royal Yeast cake.
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes, made baking powder.
Did you buy baking powder? Yes.
Did you take your own baking powder?

Cream of tartar... Did you take your own cream of tartar?

Sugar... Did you take your own sugar?

Flour... Did you take your own flour?

Salt... Did you take your own salt?

Baking soda... Did you take your own baking soda?

Vanilla... Did you take your own vanilla?

Cheese (Chester or other cheese) about 20¢ per lb. We usually bought 3 or 4 lbs. at a time.
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon               | tall tins 12¢ to 25¢                   |                              |                                               |
| Canned sardines             | 6¢ to 15¢                             |                              |                                               |
| Other canned fish that appeared early - give names |                              |                              |                                               |
| Apples - fresh              | 5¢ to 6¢ lb.                          |                              |                                               |
| dried                       | about 10¢ lb.                         |                              |                                               |
| Lettuce                     | Almost all these goods were on the grocer's shelves in town stores in 1908 onwards. |
| Tomatoes - fresh            |                                        |                              |                                               |
| canned                      |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Bananas                     |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Lemons                      |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Oranges                     | 30¢ doz. sometimes                    |                              |                                               |
| Cornflakes                  | Some of these we seldom purchased as we couldn't afford them. |
| Other prepared breakfast cereals - give names |                              |                              |                                               |
| Pearl tapioca               |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Minato tapioca              |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Sago                        |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Dates                       | 2 lbs. for 25¢                        |                              |                                               |
| Walnuts                     |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Icing sugar                 |                                        |                              |                                               |

12. WATER SUPPLY: We often melted snow during winter months and on stormy days during 1908-1909 (our 2 ocean). There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) From the well of neighbor Len Root.

How far was this water from your home? Neighbor's Well was a mile away.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) Usually by barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

We had a well dug on our homestead in the summer of 1910. It cost us over $200 for labor & lumber & when the diggers hit solid rock at about 80 feet down they gave up. This well was a failure.
11. **HEAVY PILL FOR THE AFTERTHOUGHT**

| Item                  | Amount | Description |
|-----------------------|--------|-------------|
| Caribou Cake          | 1/2 lb | Appended from the store, not all different |
| Corned & Cured        | 1/2 lb | From the store, not all different |
| Canned Apples         | 6 p    | 6 p & 15 q |
| Other canned          | 1/2 lb | 1/2 lb & 1/4 lb |
| General Curry         | 1/2 lb | 1/2 lb & 1/4 lb |
| Olive Raisins         | 1/2 lb | 1/2 lb & 1/4 lb |

**Apples - Fresh**
- 5 q to 6 q $1.00
- Dried about $1.00

**Lettuce**
- Almost all these got lost here in the process of storage in "Tinpan."

**Tomatoes - Fresh**
- Stowed in 1908 - Minnocks.

**Bananas**
- Some of these we seldom purchased as we could not afford them.

**Cornstalks**
- Other preserved vegetables - five names.

**Povri Taploa**
- Mauro Taploa

**Sago**
- 2 lbs. for 25¢

**Ice Cream**

---

12. **HEAVY PILL FOR THE AFTERTHOUGHT**

And even during my days planning 1908-1909 over 2 acres of land, there was no water for drinking and for cooking (all river, slosh, melted down) from the well stored by Mr. Root usually by himself.

How was it brought to the house? Through the well into a 7 mile long barrel. We had a well dug on our homestead in the summer of 1910. It cost us over $200 for labor & timber. In order to digger at third rock at about 80 feet deep they gave up. This will also be a failure.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought as a rule, but made same when oil was saved in sufficient quantities.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, what about?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Cowboy store, Royal Crown, also no other town brands too, as Sunlight.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal & lime and wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Coal from Yeadon (20 odd miles).

My husband went to Sandhill & of Harris & cut lots of logs there, with lots of help.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

(Being 2 long days)

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) A small iron cook stove bought in Saskatoon in 1906.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? I think the name was Clare.

What year was it purchased? 1906.

Price? With pipe $25.00

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) We bought granite ware, about 8 pieces at Saskatoon in fall of 1906.

Also a nice flat iron kettle, 2 tin pie plates, iron frying pan.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) We used earthenware crockery, bowls & bean pot & china ware dishes.

When did you first see enamel ware? All of 60 years ago, in England.

Aluminum? Coming into use in England, about 1904.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

9a Xmas dinner mentioned below
Mrs Short gave us the cornets
Mr Jensen brought a bag of apples about 7 lbs.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Oatmeal or Wheat granules porridge brown sugar
Milk (as a rule) Coffee, toast, buttered, or milk cheese.

Dinner: Potatoes - baked often in winter, French fried when there was no meat
Supper - soup all times, when we had a meal a potato pie we were living high. Syrup was always a staple.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? ...................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Our first two Christmas dinners were eaten at Warman, Sask. 1906 with Mr. & Mrs. R.E. Lane. We came to homestead in the fall of 1906 at our first Christmas dinner there we invited 2 back-else who lived near us. They were Andy Jensen (about 45) and Luke Short (about 45 yrs) and Luke Short (about 45 yrs)

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No. But we were sometimes without one or two of such things as flour, sugar, butter, milk & lard for a week or more at a time.

Christmas Dinner Menu - 1908

Prime Roast Beef
Yorkshire pudding & gravy. Mashed Potatoes
Xmas Pudding made without eggs served with nutmeg sauce.
The 3 men ate & ate and all said it was a grand dinner
4 of us present that year.

Fried Cornets.
The cornets were large & getting hard. Cut & boiled a hour or so. Drained & fried in beef drippings till slightly browned. Very good.
Our first Christmas dinner was eaten at Warren's, Sackville, Nova Scotia. We came to Homestead on the fall of 1908. We had our third new car. They were Andy Johnson (Cabot 49) and Luke Short (Cabot 45). We had more sometime without one or two of such things as flour, sugar, butter, milk, and for a week or more at a time.

Prime Royal Beef - Christmas Dinner Menu - 1908

Yorkshire pudding & gravy
Mashed Potatoes
Fried Corned Beef
Pudding made with eggs
Served with sauce
Pla 3 men ate & ate and all said very good
We won a grand dinner that year.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In our first homesteading days one table was used for meals, preparation of same & every other thing tables are used for. Also, we had fewer utensils. In 1914 our first baby was [the early day] batted on that table, too.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I think questions 21 & 22 are for those who purchased even earlier than we did.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

---

Dear ladies at the University:

I am very sorry this questionnaire has waited so long to be finished. I have had some trouble with my eyes these last 2 years & at times could neither read nor write. So perhaps your first volume is already printed. I hope this may help you with Vol. 2.

Sincerely yours, Alice L. Taylor.
In our first translation days one table was used for meals, preparation of same & very often dinner telling me head for. Also, we had fewer utensils & cooked in what table. In the early days.

9th question 21 & 22 are for those who purchased even earlier than we did.

10/16 Albert Green

May 7th, 1951

Dear Ladies at the University:

I am very sorry it's been so long & I'm finished.

I have read every word & my eyes thee that 2 years & at times could not read nor write.

So here's to your first volume in already printed.

I hope this may help you with Vol. 2.

Sincerely yours, Alice L. Taylor.
Oxford

No. 613 S

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
